Miles Sound System SDK 6.1c

AIL_set_3D_velocity_vector

The function AIL_set_3D_velocity_vector sets the current velocity of a 3D sample, the listener, or a 3D object in non-normalized coordinates.

void AIL_set_3D_velocity_vector(
  H3DPOBJECT obj,
  F32 dX_per_ms,
  F32 dY_per_ms,
  F32 dZ_per_ms
);

In Parameters

obj
indicates the 3D sample, listener, or 3D object to set the velocity of.
dX_per_ms
is the delta in meters in the X coordinate per millisecond.
dY_per_ms
is the delta in meters in the Y coordinate per millisecond.
dZ_per_ms
is the delta in meters in the Z coordinate per millisecond.

Discussion

The velocity of a 3D object is used both for calculating the Doppler pitch shift to use, as well as the amount to move the object when Miles does the repositioning with AIL_update_3D_position or AIL_auto_update_3D_position.

Note that since the distances for velocity are in meters per millisecond, the values passed to this function are generally very small. For example, at 20 miles an hour (about the fastest a human can run), you would be passing in roughly 0.009 for a non-normalized delta value.

Following DirectSound3D's somewhat awkward lead, Miles uses the left-handed coordinate system. All of DirectX also uses left-handed coordinates, so passing in coordinates from a DirectX application is simple. OpenGL, on the other hand, cleanly uses right-handed coordinates, so you must invert the sign of the Z parameter before passing it into Miles.
